newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - JULY 25.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - JULY 25.

text.p: HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - The cabinet agreed on a preliminary price of 5.88 billion crowns for the sale of 36.3 percent of IPB bank to Japanese Nomura. This is 285 crown per share, and is the market price from the day the offer was made, according to Finance Minister Ivan Pilip.

- KDU-CSL chairman Josef Lux threatened to leave the coalition yesterday. His party is upset that ODS and ODA did not vote in favour of selling Czech tanks to Algeria but did vote to sell the state's stake in IPB to Nomura.

- Defence Minister Miloslav Vyborny, visited President Vaclav Havel yesterday and informed him that he was considering resigning from his post after the cabinet rejected his proposal to sell 100 Czech T-72 tanks to Algeria. He received Havel's support and will stay in office.
- The crown strengthened again yesterday and closed at 18.70 against the mark after starting at 18.80.
- During the first half of this year, sales of passenger cars increased by 20 percent. Nearly 90,000 new cars for 20 billion crowns were sold.

MLADA FRONTA DNES - Restitucni Investicni Fond, the largest investment fund in the country, made profits of 875 million crowns during the first half of this year. Profits increased by more than one third over the end of May.

- The Exchange Chamber of the Prague Stock Exchange expelled Iceberg from the chamber and will not allow it to trade on the stock exchange for six months, because it did not meet information requirements and disregarded obligations from signed contracts.
- A commercial court in Kladno ruled to make Poldi Steel's subsidiaries, Poldi Uslechtile Oceli and Poldi Konstrukcni Oceli, bankrupt.
- In a general meeting, shareholders of Chemapol Group approved plans to issue bonds of up to five billion crowns by the end of the century.
- By July 20, Komercni Banka, the largest domestic bank, had sold nearly half of its new global deposit receipts of three percent of its basic capital through the Bank of New York.

- The banking commission of parliament requested a report from the central bank on whether the bank regularly informed minority shareholders of Agrobanka about the course of forced administration. The commission wants to resolve the situation by this September.
- The European Commission announced an ultimatum to the Czech Republic yesterday that the import deposit system should be cancelled by the end of July.
PRAVO - From today, Komercni Banka will decrease its reference rate by 0.8 percentage points to 15.60 percent. Its base rate will decrease by 0.75 percentage points to 13.90 percent.
- According to a cabinet decision, the Czech Republic will return gold to Slovak jews which was taken by the state during World War II and was deposited into Czechoslovak government banks.
- The border between the Czech Republic and Slovakia will change today. The Czech Republic will receive Sidonie, and Slovakia will receive U Sabotu.

- During a tripartite meeting yesterday, government representatives, labour unions and employers agreed on a new order for talks. Labour unions succeeded in stopping preparations for a new law on strikes.
LIDOVE NOVINY - The Czech National Bank decreased its two-week repo rate to 15.2 percent yesterday.
- Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus left for a holiday to the Austrian Alps. He will return on August 5. Until then, Environment Minister and Cabinet Vice-chairman Jiri Skalicky will take over his duties.
